titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George J. Bischof papers ARC.008
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Weatherly Stephan
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources with additional support from the Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation. Photographs from this collection were digitized as part of Project CHART (Cultural Heritage Access Research and Technology); a collaboration between the Brooklyn Historical Society, Brooklyn Museum and Brooklyn Public library with the Pratt Institute. Funded through an IMLS grant sponsored by the Laura Bush 21st Century Librarian program.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-06-07T16:11-0400

change.item: Photographic subseries Revised in 2013 by Caridad Bojorquez [photointern].

did.unittitle: George J. Bischof papers and photographs

physdesc.extent: in two folders and three oversize photograph folders.

did.abstract: This collection, dated 1900 to 1941, contains correspondence, a news clipping, photographs, and a life membership card for the Brooklyn Engineers Club, all pertaining to George J. Bischof and his employment as an engineer for the Borough of Brooklyn. Two black-and-white photographs show staff members of the Office of the Brooklyn Borough President during the time of Bischof's employment.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: George J. Bischof (1866-1953) was employed as a civil engineer for the Harlem River Bridge Commission in Manhattan, N.Y. in 1887, and joined the New York City Department of Parks in 1889. As a result of the consolidation of the five New York City boroughs, Bischof was transferred to the Office of the Brooklyn Borough President in 1902. In Brooklyn, Bischof served as an engineer for local boards of the Bureau of Sewers and the Topographical Bureau, where he remained until his retirement in 1936.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This collection, dated 1900 to 1941, contains correspondence, a news clipping, photographs, and a life membership card for the Brooklyn Engineers Club, all pertaining to George J. Bischof and his employment as an engineer for the Borough of Brooklyn. Two black-and-white photographs show staff members of the Office of the Brooklyn Borough President during the time of Bischof's employment.

The photographs are organized into two series: George J. Bischof photographs, and Joseph P. Hall photographs. The George J. Bischof photographs are personal and related to his career as an engineer. The Joseph P. Hall photographs are black-and-white prints of waterfront stores, mounted accordion style, of piers and stores on the waterfront in the Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, and Red Hook neighborhoods of Brooklyn, circa 1900.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); George J. Bischof papers, ARC.008, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.
This collection combines two accessions: 1991.029 and V1991.090.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids note
otherfindaid.p: Item-level description and digital versions of images from the collection are available for searching via the image database in the library.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Reproduction rights for photographs have not been evaluated. Please consult library staff for more information.

originalsloc.head: Existence and Location of Originals note
originalsloc.p: Item-level description and digital revisions of images from the collection are available for searching via the online image database.
